key_points: 90 million stimulus checks were sent out last week as part of the $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan.
Americans who didn't receive their 2020 stimulus checks can get the money through Recovery Rebate Credits by filing their 2020 federal taxes.
Certain debts like child support, back taxes, and other outstanding debts may reduce your tax return if you receive your stimulus as a Recovery Rebate Credit.
The December $900 billion Covid relief bill protected the second round of stimulus checks from all creditor garnishment, including private creditors.
Tax refunds, including stimulus received as a tax rebate, may be reduced to pay back various debts through the Treasury Offset Program (TOP).
The IRS will not use stimulus rebates to pay for federal tax debts, but cannot prevent offsets for state and other federal agency debts.
The $1,400 stimulus check under the American Rescue Plan is not subject to garnishment for unpaid federal or state debts, but can be for private debts under a court order.
Consumer advocacy and banking groups are urging Congress to pass legislation to exempt the latest stimulus payments from garnishment.
The American Bankers Association and Americans for Financial Reform are among the groups advocating for this legislation.
The IRS's Get My Payment site can be used to track the status of the third stimulus payment.
